DetailContent.body: Bradycardia in theatre should not be treated as an isolated variable: remember to tailor treatment to the patient and the situation. Follow the full steps to exclude a serious underlying problem.

DetailContent.head: Immediate action
DetailContent.body:
Stop any stimulus, check pulse, rhythm and blood pressure:

  • If no pulse OR not sinus bradycardia OR severe hypotension: use Box A.
  • If pulse present AND sinus bradycardia: use Box B.

DetailContent.head: Box A: CRITICAL BRADYCARDIA
DetailContent.body:
Give atropine 20 µg.kg⁻¹ (adult 0.5-1 mg) with fluid flush.

If no pulse: (or heart rate <60 bpm infant or neonate):

Delegate (minimum) 1 person to chest compressions

→2-1 (Cardiac arrest)

DetailContent.head: Box B: DRUGS FOR BRADYCARDIA
DetailContent.body:
• Glycopyrrolate 5 µg.kg⁻¹ (adult 200-400 µg)
  • Ephedrine 100 µg.kg⁻¹ (adult 3-12 mg)
  • Atropine 10 µg.kg⁻¹ (adult 300-600 µg)
  • Isoprenaline 0.5 µg.kg.min⁻¹ (adult 5 µg.min⁻¹)
  • Adrenaline 1 µg.kg⁻¹ (adult 10-100 µg) in emergency only

DetailContent.head: Adequate oxygen delivery
DetailContent.body:
• Check fresh gas flow for circuit in use AND check measured FiO₂.
  • Visual inspection of entire breathing system including valves and connections.
  • Rapidly confirm reservoir bag moving OR ventilator bellows moving.

DetailContent.head: Airway
DetailContent.body:
• Check position of airway device and listen for noise (including larynx and stomach).
  • Check capnogram shape compatible with patent airway.
  • Confirm airway device is patent (consider passing suction catheter).

DetailContent.head: Breathing
DetailContent.body:
• Check chest symmetry, rate, breath sounds, SpO₂, measured VTexp, ETCO₂.
  • Feel the airway pressure using reservoir bag and APL valve <3 breaths.

DetailContent.head: Circulation
DetailContent.body: Check rate, rhythm, perfusion, recheck blood pressure.

DetailContent.head: Depth
DetailContent.body: Consider current depth of anaesthesia AND adequacy of analgesia.

DetailContent.head: Box C: POTENTIAL UNDERLYING PROBLEMS
DetailContent.body:
• Consider whether you could have made a drug error
  • Consider known drug causes (eg. remifentanil, digoxin etc)
  • Surgical stimulation with inadequate depth
  • Also consider: high intrathoracic pressure; pneumoperitoneum; local anaesthetic toxicity →3-10; beta-blocker; digoxin; calcium channel blocker; myocardial infarction, hyperkalaemia, hypothermia, raised intra-cranial pressure
Call for help if problem not resolving quickly.

DetailContent.head: Box D: TRANSCUTANEOUS PACING
DetailContent.body:
• Attach pads and ECG leads from pacing defibrillator
  • Set to PACING MODE
  • Set PACER RATE
  • Increase PACER OUTPUT from 60 mA until capture (spikes align QRS)
  • Confirm capture: electrical AND mechanical (femoral pulse)
  • Set PACER OUTPUT 10 mA above capture

DetailContent.head: The guidelines in this handbook are not intended to be standards of medical care. The ultimate judgement with regard to a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the clinician in the light of the clinical data presented and the diagnostic and treatment options available.
